text: i really am thrilled to be here at stanford it's just so exciting to be back with a a large community and you
know working as an artist i work with teams a lot but i pretty much work you know on my own not not in a broad
research community so i mean there's a community of artists but it's not who i was engaging with on a day to day basis
so it's really fun to be back here um i was saying at lunch it's interesting
for me also to think about giving a talk like this as to what issues would be of interest to you guys
you know i'm often i really am operating largely in the fine art community so we like to talk about you know certain
kinds of conceptual things but design has always played a really important role in my work because i am
making installations that engage with people so i'm going to try to focus a little bit on the actual interaction design of the works
that i'm doing and the first one like when you said that i'd like to show you is texturing
i created this with a fellow masters student at the nyu interactive telecommunications program which is
where i was doing my degree i guess i should say a little about my background my undergrad degree was in fine art
but i had i almost double majored in environmental science so i was always interested in systems and how the
parameters of a system interacted and when i saw kind of early cd-roms this ancient technology which most of
you probably haven't dealt with interactive cd-roms this is kind of also in the in the dawn of the internet when
you couldn't really put images and movies online yet um the ability to craft a space that like this
metaphorical space that people could navigate through that was the words we used at the time you know by choosing their path of how
they clicked on on different icons or worked with different imagery in that that cd-rom space is what got me
interested in programming so i started learning how to program and eventually went back to this program where i eventually as my thesis project
and then also continuing on as a researcher at interval research they sponsored me after i graduated and these
were the kind of projects i was doing so i'm going to play a little video
tech strain is a playful interactive installation that blurs the boundary between the familiar and the magical
participants in the text drain installation use the familiar instrument of their bodies to lift and play with
falling letters that do not really exist like rain or snow the colored text can
be caught lifted and then let fall again if a participant accumulates enough
letters along their outstretched arms they can sometimes catch a word or even a phrase
oops i thought this was a longer version of the installation you know what i'm going to pop over to my dvd
sorry
uh
sorry i'll get to watch that beginning again there's a lot more so i wanted you to see the rest of it
tech stream is a playful interactive installation that blurs the boundary between the familiar and the magical
participants in the text drain installation use the familiar instrument of their bodies to do what seems magical
to lift and play with falling letters that do not really exist like rain or snow the colored text
appears to land on participants heads and arms the text responds to the participants motions and can be caught
lifted and then let fall again the falling text will land on anything
darker than a certain threshold and fall whenever that obstacle is removed
if a participant accumulates enough letters along their outstretched arms or along the silhouette of any dark object
they can sometimes catch a word or even a phrase the following letters are not random but
form lines of a poem about bodies and language
so
so we were talking at lunch about um the text that's actually part of this piece and you know what is the importance of
that could i switch it to a twitter feed or something like that and romy and i really thought carefully
about what that text was it's a poem um that is about this kind of slippage between our is it really a conversation
or is something physical happening between these two people um and i think we still struggle with this
issue with with all our devices of like sort of what is where does our body live in in all of this and so that's that's
sort of a key issue that i i think i've explored with all of my work so again this was 1999 so before opencv
like really really early examples of computer vision kind of installations um
it was it's interesting to think back on that time most people were actually the thing they were most shocked about first when they saw this was the projector
right so they're like how do you get that image so big you know and then they would be like how am i in that image and
then they would come to realize like oh there's this these texts there's things i can actually um that can land on my
body um so i like to think too in any kind of interaction design like what's that sort of ramp in to discovering more
and more things so once they worked out that they could catch the letters um at first that's really exciting but then
there's this whole other layer that whoa there's actually some words in there it's not totally random but it's really
hard to read the whole poem so i don't think that anyone ever gets that all exactly but part of it is that there is
some meaning that's kind of always just a little bit outside of your grasp which again is something that's kind of
interesting to me as an artist um and then there's the social layer as well so if you're in the space alone you can
have that kind of interaction but often like you saw in the video when people are there they find different ways to kind of try
to work together or get the letters from somebody else and there's a there's a few design
components of this work that i've been thinking about i just showed it again in san jose in a show called patent pending
which is all artists who have dealt with the ip or ip system in some way or another so
um partly because of the fact i was employed by interval and their relationship with nyu nyu decided to patent this
while i was there so i have engaged i have a patent well nyu owns that romy and i are the inventors um
but that that was an interesting show looking at artists as uh engaging with with the patent system in different ways
but watching this piece again you know it's been shown all over the place and i don't always go to install it anymore so
watching um really young people encounter this for the first time i'm always wondering like is there going to
come a point where this kind of interaction becomes not interesting anymore right because now we see this
kind of in airports and you know for advertising it's you know you can do it
with your connect at home you know so does it does it become a gimmick um and i think there's a way where it
has even surprised me kind of how people still find a rich engagement in this work and i've been trying to analyze
that a bit which is something you all maybe could help me with since i don't i don't write research papers on the actual interaction design but i think
there's some really simple choices that romy and i made you know maybe intuitively or justif by luck
that help with that um one of them is no matter how many people are in this space they're not occluding or they they
are occluding each other but even if there's like just this tiny tiny like fringe at the top where the letters are falling you can still reach your hands
above other people and get get them and so just by nature of the fact that there's something falling from the top
of the screen even in a really crowded space it's it the interaction everyone can still have
the interaction and it actually gets kind of fun that you're you can stand behind someone and try to reach above their head to get the
letter so i tried you know i've done lots of other kinds of installations using cameras in a silhouette view like
that um and you always have this problem that if someone's behind the other person they're kind of not part of the interaction in some way so that that
maybe was just luck based on on this idea that we were exploring um the fact that the people are in black and white
and the letters are in color i think is important so i think there's this this idea and a lot of interactive installation that the more we add the
better it is you know the sort of more hyper-realistic it is the more you feel like you're in the actual environment um
but i think there's a kind of there's something very compelling about seeing yourself in black and white which kind
of removes you from reality and the letters being in color so there's always this distinction between the thing
you're engaging with and your representation of yourself um we often argue with people
back to my powerpoint not argue but um when we install this
piece let's go back to this one um about you know it's it's pretty hard to
get the camera always in the middle of the screen it means you can't use a screen like this you have to cut a hole in the wall
and everyone always would prefer can't you put the camera on top of the screen or below the screen but there's a really simple reason why
that's super critical which is people's line of sight right so if you've ever skyped and had a
camera that wasn't the camera in your laptop when we used to have the other ones it could be somewhere else you
realize how totally distracting it gets when you're you can't look at the other person in the screen and make kind of
eye contact with them which is just an illusion of where the camera is right so now since the camera's right here when
i'm skating with someone it's pretty close to my line of sight similarly to how here we have it in the middle of the
screen if it was up above it'd kind of be looking down at you and you wouldn't like literally be able to look at
someone else the way these people are in the screen so there's this this real illusion that you can communicate with a
person standing right next to you by by looking in this sort of mirror like space together
um let's see what else do i want to say i think that's it for now
i'm sure i'll leave time for questions about this um but again this idea of what's what's the role of our body in
relation to these systems and i guess one other thing my favorite moment in that video is when the little boy turns the umbrella upside down
right because he's making a hypothesis about how the system works and is is then making his next attempt to test it
out right if i can catch the letters on the top of the umbrella what happens if i turn the umbrella upside down so i
think those kind of moments are what really got me hooked on on being an interactive artist so this was really one of the first major pieces i did
and then i just wanted to keep doing it because because of creating those kind of spaces for people
um i started thinking more about the way we use language in relation to
our body so we often say like what's your position on this issue where do you stand
right and we mean that like you know what are your political views or what's your you know scholarly position on this
um but i was thinking about about that as in a very literal sense like that that stems from a literal
position that you may be standing in and i wanted to create a place a space that again was a multi-user
uh so thinking back again to this time it this this idea of a social engagement with a computer was very very different
than it is now so i wanted to create that kind of space um but i was thinking about could i could i
make a shared space on the screen that also represented like literally having these different viewpoints so
that it wasn't a coherent space um in a sort of linear one-point perspective photographic way right so
computers are really really good at rendering something you know based on this formula that we have a camera over
here and these objects here and we're going to project them onto a flat plane which is the computer you know then
we'll render that and that'll be the computer's computer screen but if you look at art history that's that that
kind of way of depicting space is a very small part of our history and there's lots of artists that have
worked with other ways of of creating space um and representing reality a reality so like picasso and the cubists
um you know like to position lots of different things together on the screen on their painting surfaces so i was
thinking about that um i'll let you watch this and then i'll explain a little more how i got there
and so the original this is a series i continued so what i'm showing you is actually a more recent piece in this
series
shifting time san jose is an interactive video installation that juxtaposes the
past and present using the viewer's body as the interface to navigate between
different times in this piece commissioned by the city of san jose for
a new terminal of the san jose international airport viewers first encounter a projected
still image as they walk closer to the projection wall the surface disrupts
revealing deeper moments of time in the pre-recorded video clips
viewers are able to shift between past and present by moving towards and away
from the projection wall shifting time san jose continues
utterback's liquid time series which uses her custom software to deconstruct
the video frame as the unit of playback this strategy of fragmentation allows
multiple moments to appear simultaneously and speaks to the possibilities of digital tools as well
as the fluidity of our personal memories
unlike the previous liquid timepieces shifting time san jose extends the period of time depicted from
seconds to decades in this work high definition video
footage from the present blends with archival film footage from the 1920s through the 1960s
each of the 20 scenes in shifting time san jose pairs footage of a historic
site or activity in the san jose area with complementary contemporary footage
some scenes depict recognizable locations in both the past and present
other scenes show people working at industries long gone paired with employees in the current high-tech
sector pleasure and travel scenes from past eras are paired with their contemporary
counterparts different forms of stasis and change are
revealed as time shifts subtly within each clip and more drastically between the different eras of historic time
as the past visually intersperses with the present shifting time san jose creates an
intriguing visual metaphor of how both history and our memories of a place
contribute to our experience of the present moment
so in the end the piece the piece i developed is still using um you know one point linear perspective as as conveyed
by a lens um but that wasn't sort of where i started that's that's where the piece ended up so one thing that's great about being an artist is you can kind of
follow the mistakes and and take advantage of the things that are happening so what i first started doing when i was set out to do this is i
imagine the space in front of the screen is kind of having maybe seven or eight different zones in it and as you move
forward and backward closer or further away from the screen you would get whatever type of imagery was in those
those zones and i was coding this myself so it had these lists of the different images that you were kind of moving through as you
move back and forth and different people could be in like a different layer at a time because if i was you know this person could be there and i could be
here so i liked that idea that you were getting these different perspectives together and i sort of kept making more and more
and more layers and this list was getting longer and longer and i had this very like aha moment that a list of
images in the computer is a video file which is sort of obvious but i think a
lot of people don't understand that if you haven't been sort of trying to access one image and print it to the screen and get the next image in the
queue um so i decided hey what would happen if if these layers that you were
moving through were kind of infinitely thin and it was actually each one was a frame of you know 24 frames per second or
whatever video so that visually was a lot more interesting than my original premise
um and in the earlier pieces like the voiceover said it was it would be one clip that you were moving through so
like 10 seconds of time not like what you just saw where i was pairing up that the present five seconds or ten seconds
with a really deep past another five or ten seconds um if you want to think i think a lot of people have now seen this
it's often called slit scan i didn't know about that when i was first working on this but there as soon as you start
looking at the um the frame data as digital information it's very easy to take a slice of that
video frame right like when video was was um film and it was like
literally um you know a celluloid square after a celluloid square after a cellulite
square it's really hard to physically take a little stripe of that out and put it next to another one but once it's
it's in the computer you can easily get at any pixel so i think there's a lot of people now kind of experimenting in this
way where they're pulling um they're looking at that volume of video data as data not frame by frame by frame but
it's a sort of interesting premise like just because we recorded this information in one structure why do we
have to play it back using that same structure and for those of you that aren't really familiar with this a way to think about
it is that if you imagine the video is a flip book that's stapled along the top you know like one of those little paper
flip books and then cut a whole bunch of slices in it vertically then you can flip any of those vertical strips
independently of each other so that's sort of the effect that i'm creating um and i think another important thing
which wasn't obvious to me at the time but like the more and more popular different computer vision systems become
is that in both text reading this i'm kind of using a really dumb algorithm because i was just learning
how to do all this i don't have any kind of skeleton constructed in either of these pieces i don't even
have blob detection like i don't even know that this area is a person i'm really just looking at the contours of
your body right so in text screen the space is set up very specifically so there's a white wall behind you so even if you're
wearing a white shirt you're darker than the wall you know so there's no reference frame for those of you that do computer vision so it's just
looking for dark above a certain threshold which i set up in this space um and in this piece it's
really doing the same thing but the camera's on the ceiling looking down so like your nose is deeper into time than
your shoulders um but what i found is there's more and more of these tools are available it's actually like we're
dumbing down the body right so even though we have a very sophisticated model like what you can get through the um the connect
api you know we know exactly where the joints are and how your hands are moving
a lot of really rich information is thrown out i think or it's not it's not actively used as much as it could be so
if you think about the in texturing like how someone's arms like the letters can
really um build along their contour or in this piece how you know like what i just said your nose is actually deeper
than your shoulders and you get these kind of really interesting um undulations i feel like a lot of that
has is sort of not being used in a lot of the not all but in a lot of the computer visions vision systems that i
see it's like because we have this other higher level information we've kind of lost some of what the camera can give us
as an input device so that's something i've been thinking about a little bit lately um
i want to point out this uh circle of light on the floor too um when i first did this piece i didn't
indicate the interaction area at all and it was kind of a failure because people couldn't understand like
that they could see all this energy changing but it wasn't super obvious to them especially like at an opening when there was a lot of people around
where the interaction was in the space because there's no indication of your body unlike text rate it's really clear
when you're in or out of the piece and so i started experimenting with different ways to indicate that some of
the failed ones were like at one gallery i had there was a very shiny floor and i put some like sort of thin pvc stuff
down like kind of matte you know like doormat kind of stuff and people started doing this
right because you're giving them this indication that that's some sort of sensor on the floor
um and so their testing out of the system was giving them the completely the wrong clue um so i tried other ways
of marking the floor and in the end this this sort of square of light um is something i've used and some of the
other pieces i'll show you too because there's a really nice connection between the projection being light and this light on the floor
being the same you know indicated not with pain or not with something else that wouldn't confuse people that it was a sensor
but it has sort of the same visual characteristics so i just wanted to point that out um and in the airport
piece the video we couldn't get this kind of rectangle because of the height of the ceiling so we did little corner squares which would not be
not my preference but this is the piece of the airport again
so just some images this is one of my favorites it was really fun to shoot the archival footage or we looked for the
art sorry we did all the research to find the archival footage and then we had to figure out what to pair it with
but this one of the women's sorting fruit and the woman programming this idea of again what's the role of our
body in these different forms of work is interesting to me
so the next series i'm going to show you i won't show you all the pieces but it's kind of an extended uh series i've done called external
measures where i started thinking about could i make something on a screen that was a drawing
system that you know is algorithmically reacting to people's movement in the space
that that both generated something visually interesting and was also interesting for people physically as
they interacted in the space right so i think if you guys think about other kinds of interactive art that you've seen there are a lot of projects where
the interaction is sort of conceptual meaning it might be important to the idea of the
piece but you it's very hard for you to experience it right you it's very hard for you to test how
it's actually reacting to you or you have these mistaken cues like i was talking about um
so i was it was really important to me in these that you could like the little boy turning over the umbrella like slowly test the different
parts of the system and how it was reacting to you um so this was the first one um you can see how people are
indicated as they're the negative space so their bodies actually erase what's on the screen
and i'm not going to show video of this one because it was one of the earlier ones but the um there was like a network of
little gray lines that was always spinning and whenever it intersected with you it had to this i got blob detection working so
you would be assigned a color when you walked into the space and anything that hit you would turn that color and then keep going so there was also this sense
that you had influenced this bigger system but it was doing its own thing independently of you
there's a screenshot of it and then these are two of the next
pieces untitled five and untitled six and i'm going to show you video of untitled five and you know what i'm
going to flip back to the dvd because this might be a short one too i didn't test these videos bad
untitled five is the fifth interactive installation in the external measures series which utterback has been
developing since 2001. the goal of these works is to create an aesthetic system which responds fluidly
and intriguingly to physical movement in the exhibit space in these dynamic works the position's
velocity and existence of various parts of a projected image depend on people's presence and movement
some responses are direct and immediate other behaviors evolve over time based on the flow of people in the space
in untitled five a network of gray lines flickers around one's body and immediately indicates your presence
a colored line is drawn along your trajectory when you leave the installation this line is filled with tiny marks
these marks can now be pushed from their location by other people's movement displaced marks attempt to return to
their original location creating smears and streaks of color as they move
these painterly swaths are the results of intersections between current and previous motion in the space
conceptually linking disparate moments in time untitled 5 reacts to stillness as well
as motion standing in place sets off a delicate spray of dots which radiate from the
center of one's body while one's presence generates marks it also erases older marks
the rules of untitled five are carefully constructed to create an overall composition that is organic open and
evocative while still being completely algorithmic while the specific rules of the system
are never explicitly revealed to participants the internal structure and composition of the piece can be
discovered through a process of kinesthetic exploration
engaging with this work creates a visceral sense of unfolding or revelation but also a feeling of immediacy and loss
that was the floor that didn't work very well that the experience of this work is the
experience of embodied existence itself a continual flow of unique and fleeting
moments
so in this i was kind of splitting the difference of those of two ways of looking at at human movement that i was
just talking about so the line that's being drawn obviously i'm reducing you to a point it's the center of your blob
but that kind of gray mesh around the outside of your body still has that richness of really the contours of what
you look like and the other thing that i think
is still kind of unique about this piece compared to some similar types of installations is that it's not just
doing one thing there's not one rule right so in text reading the rule is really simple the letters have to land
on anything that's darker than the background but there is a richness both because of the way it's it's it's
following the contours of your body and the fact that there's text that you can or cannot decipher and the social interactions that develop but the actual
rule of the system is very very simple um very same same with the liquid time piece right though i described how
you're like flipping through these pieces of video but it's kind of one rule there's not a lot
there's a little bit of how far you get those strips messed up they take a little time to return to stillness but
it's really the same rule set in these i was really looking at them as a kind of larger composition like how could i as
an artist think of each of these rules as sort of one element and a bigger picture no no pun intended
and how did each of those rules function in in the overall experience so some of them like the line the little gray lines
really help you find where you are the other one tells you something about time passing right because the line is
building up and then i think what's most interesting about this piece and this is the one in the series where i really got to this
was that the things that are happening don't just have to do with you right so a lot of our interaction design
it's very sort of like egocentric and it's all about you and everything you're doing and you you you right and
immediately immediately immediate immediate feedback right so but with this system um what
the voiceover is trying to describe is that i'm looking at the visual marks that get laid down as a sort of history
but because it's it's not a paint line that's fixed it's actually a history that's in code
i can then have the people in the space that come later that have their movement intersect with
that past movement so i don't know if that made sense from the voiceover but like if i if i walk in one line through the space the little
marks are holding their sizes based on how fast i was going and they obviously know the xy position
that they got laid down on if another person walks through they have to get pushed away
so there's already one interaction between the past and the present but they have a rule that they're trying to go back then when the second person gets
out of the way to their original location so the the thing that's drawing the most in this piece is that
difference between someone that was there in the past where they walked and someone that was there now so i think
again this is an area that there's still a lot of space to explore that of how we can show these connections
between different uh different moments in time and i don't think people ever under figure this all out either so in terms
of the interaction design hopefully what makes these works compelling you know there's a lot of collectors that now
have them um either in lobbies or homes um they're not like a one-liner right
but they're also not inscrutable so when you walk into this installation you can find yourself like you can test
oh there's my arm you know i see myself um you can see some things that are very clearly reacting to you and understand
why but there's there's that layer of connection with the past that's always a little hard to totally decipher
so it doesn't become predictable and i think those again are kind of metaphors of interaction
we could stand to think more about
there it is in a lobby and here unfortunately i wasn't able to convince them to do any kind of light on
the floor the ceiling was pretty low so and and often here's the problem being an artist too i install these things and
i don't always get a chance to go back and analyze what's happening so this is a lobby in hong kong i can't really tell
you if how much people there um understand the piece but the the fact that it's a it's a residential lobby and
people live there makes me think that eventually they would come to sort of understand what uh where
the interaction area is here and here's i had a chance to install all three of these at the milwaukee art
museum and this was the first time i i really started making some conclusions about how the animations that were generated in
each work change people's behaviors so in like the first piece that was always moving which you didn't see video
of i noticed this is very anecdotal so i'd love an hdi person to analyze this
more fully at some point i found it made people really twitchy because every time they walked into the space they affected
the system they left it started rewriting over where they were it's like you don't like this idea that whatever
you just inscribed into this piece is vanishing so people would like fee they were much more like in out in out in out
whereas untitled five which i just showed you you know once it comes to stillness it stays that way even if it's
three hours until another person comes into the space so people would step out and watch the work and then it was
almost like the opposite if you stepped into the interaction area you were making a state change from it being
still and really beautiful to who knows if you're going to mess it up or you know you're activating it again so there was almost i wouldn't say a hesitation
because people would get really excited but it felt very different to step into that piece than in
into the piece on the left even though you know sort of ostensibly they're just all these drawing systems um so i think there's a lot there could be some
interesting research in there i'm going to go a little faster through some of these bigger pieces which is mainly what
i've been doing for the past i guess six or seven years this is 2007 on the san jose city hall
so i had a chance to put a camera up in the dome and watch the whole plaza
um a lot of things didn't work well scaled up so luckily it was a temporary installation but i got to change it
every night so the pictures of it look really different i was trying to figure out also because this surface is so complicated like how to help people see
themselves in some of those ways i was talking about before so i had to get sort of more and more obvious and more and more bold for people to see
um and i started trying to do things like um have certain behaviors when a group would form which were sort of
moderately successful there's me like testing one program and running another one and then i would swap things over
the next day if i liked what i had been so there's two parallel machines that are each with the same
camera input originally i wanted to skim this surface to make a nice clean surface
you learn a lot of interesting things working with public spaces that was not allowed on the city hall because it
would have set a precedent for hanging banners on the city hall so i had to work with the surface that
was there which in the end turned out to be really kind of beautiful um you know how the light was hitting all
these the front layer and this back layer so that idea comes back in the last piece i'll show you
um this is a piece called aurora oregon sorry that piece is called abundance um this is aurora organ from 2009 um it's
in a movie theater like the lobby of a movie theater in st louis park minnesota it's right outside of minneapolis
um i'm going to talk a tiny bit about the um the space as as part of the um
interaction design um so the piece i'll show you a video clip of it in a second but there's there's capacitance sensors
along the hand railing and how people touch that affects the patterns and the hanging lights
but the original spec that i was asked to summon a proposal for was to create a video piece an interactive video piece
like what you've been seeing on this wall here um there's a lot of problems with that number one it's this huge glass atrium
right i was like this is you know the budget is not big enough to have the projector power
to cover that um but i also didn't think that that from the way that people would walk through this space made a lot of
sense right they talked about um the the stakeholders here talked about wanting to create a social interaction and a
sense of drama and a space and i thought well you know the people are coming into this space through these stairs coming
up these escalators and if you want to create a social interaction don't you want to focus people around that like
not have them be standing looking at this other wall um so my proposal was to activate the
handrailing as the site of the interaction again to focus people in not have them all be looking up
at this other wall and i said if you have a physical if the output of this interaction is physical
even if there are times of the day where the leds are also going to be struggling against the sun it has a presence it's not just gone
so it activates the space visually even when it's not totally visible so here's a little clip of it
i think let's go back to the dvd
dvd to the rescue
aurora organ is a contemporary meditation on the possibilities of translating human presence into light
using digital technology commissioned by forecast public art and duke realty for the city of st louis
park minnesota this site-specific interactive sculpture is installed in the 80-foot atrium of
the showplace theaters located at the shops at west end in st louis park
the piece combines custom software rgb leds touch sensors and traditional
sculptural materials to create an intriguing experience for theater goers
as people touch or tap the handrailing around the building's stairwell these intimate gestures are amplified into
architectural scale patterns of light in the aurora organ sculpture six light
columns hang at various elevations above the theater entrance
on the second floor landing six illuminated glass sensors are inset in the wooden handrailing and cycle through
a palette of colors beckoning viewers to approach each time a person taps or touches a
railing sensor a pulse of the current railing color is added to the corresponding column
the length of each pulse depends on the length of time a person touches the railing holding the railing sensor creates a
long streak of color while tapping creates shorter bursts
new colors overlay and blend with previous patterns in the columns creating a record of past and present
activity at the railings each column of aurora organ becomes a
temporal history and amplified visual trace of people's presence and activity in the atrium

the more people engage with the sculpture while the patterns created by people's actions in aurora organ are ultimately
transient the bursts of light created by the most recent participants continue to cycle in the columns even after these
people have gone left alone aurora organ echoes these patterns in the empty lobby

flourish is a 70 foot long site specific installation commissioned for a major thoroughfare in a corporate headquarters
in boston massachusetts the work combines utterback's interactive installation techniques with
a new display method projection onto multiple layers of custom
glass utterback created the interactive content for flourish with animator and frequent collaborator michelle higa fox
flourish consists of seven distinct panels a triptych seen from a connecting glass
walkway and a set of four panels along the
extended thoroughfare three of the panels in the hallway are
interactive the glass panels and flourish contain
hand-painted areas of iridescent opaque and translucent glazing along with
intricate sandblasted details each panel functions as a static work of art
but at certain times of day a new dimension is revealed through the interactive projections
the double layers of glass in each panel give the projected light actual physical depth
projected elements can land on opaque glass in the front panel back panel or travel all the way through
to the background wall
the varied surface of each panel allows projected light to reflect off the opaque areas
combined with the glazing colors and cast focused shadows behind the intricate sandblasting
the complex effects of the projected light hitting different surfaces and depths in the glass creates a mysterious
viewing experience where viewers must decipher what is static and what is changing
as viewers walk by the interactive panels their movements are tracked by overhead video cameras
projected elements that correspond to the glass designs react to viewers presence
dynamic swaths of color and swirls of particles trace viewers movements along the hall
